data.title: Frock Flicks Guide to Lesser French Queens on Film: 4th through 14th centuries
data.meta_description: I admit it, I am totally a (historical) royals geek. Of course, I understand that royalty are just people, some of whom arenât very interesting or nice. But especially when I was younger, I read nuâ¦
data.text:
I admit it, I am totally a (historical) royals geek. Of course, I understand that royalty are just people, some of whom arenât very interesting or nice. But especially when I was younger, I read numerous âQueens of Englandâ books and biographies of various queens. I always think about doing social media theme days with images of different queens, then get disappointed when I realize that there arenât enough movies/TV series to make it worthwhile. I did the English queens in three posts, now I have to do the French!

BEFORE YOU FREAK OUT, I am consciously skipping these people who are worthy of (or already have) their own posts:

Eleanor of Aquitaine

Catherine de’ Medici

Mary, Queen of Scots

Margaret of Valois

Anne of Austria

FranÃ§oise d’AubignÃ©, Marquise de Maintenon

Marie Antoinette of Austria

JosÃ©phine de Beauharnais

Marie Louise, Duchess of Parma

Marie ThÃ©rÃ¨se of France

EugÃ©nie de Montijo

Iâm mostly working with Wikipedia data here, so if you know of a movie or TV series that has included any French queens, please feel free to add it in the comments! If theyâre not listed here, itâs because I canât find any onscreen portrayals. Also, I donât wanna hear any bitching about the term âlesser.â I mean âless frequently depicted.â Breathe.

Radegund of Poitiers (c. 539-61)

A ThuringianÂ princess, she was one of six wives of Clotaire I, king of the Franks. SheÂ founded theÂ Abbey of the Holy CrossÂ atÂ Poitiers.

Fredegund (c.Â 545-597)

Born into a low-ranking family but marriedÂ ChilpericÂ I, theÂ MerovingianÂ FrankishÂ king ofÂ Soissons. She has a bad reputation (deserved?) and was “put aside” for another woman by her husband, but after his deathÂ served as regent for her son fromÂ 584-97.

She was played by Diane Delor inÂ L’Enfant des loupsÂ (1991). I can’t find a photo…

Hildegard of the Vinzgau (771-83)

The daughter of CountÂ Gerold of Kraichgau, she was the second wife of Charlemagne.

Anne of Kiev (1051-60)

Daughter ofÂ Yaroslav the Wise,Â Grand Prince of Kiev, she married Henry I. She served as regent for her son fromÂ 1060-65, and founded St. Vincent Abbey in Senlis. I can’t find an even vaguely-contemporary image of the real deal!

Blanche of Castile (1223-26)

Daughter ofÂ Alfonso VIII,Â King of Castile, she marriedÂ Louis VIII. She was involved in politics and organized armies in support of her husband multiple times. She served as regent for her son during his minority (1226-34) and again when he was on Crusade (1248-52).

Margaret of Provence (1234-70)

Daughter of Ramon Berenguer IV, Count of Provence, she married Louis IX. Her sisters were also queens: Eleanor of England, Sanchia of Germany, and Beatrice of Sicily. She joined her husband on crusade and was very politically active.

Margaret of Burgundy (1305-15)

Daughter ofÂ Robert II, Duke of Burgundy, she married Louis X of France and I of Navarre. She was caught up in a scandal when she and her sisters-in-law were accused of committing adultery in the “Tour de Nesle affair,” and she spent the last two years of her life in prison.Â I can’t find an even vaguely-contemporary image of the real deal! Maybe because she was considered a hoooor?

Clementia of Hungary (1315-16)

She was the daughter ofÂ Charles Martel of Anjou, the titularÂ King of Hungary, although she was born and grew up in Naples. She was the second wife of Louis X of France/I of Navarre, who died shortly after their marriage while she was pregnant (the baby died). She continued to be active in royal life in Paris thereafter.

Joan II, Countess of Burgundy (1315-30)

She was the daughter ofÂ Otto IV, Count of Burgundy, andÂ Mahaut, Countess of Artois. She married Philip V and ruled as Countess of Burgundy and Countess of Artois. She was implicated as possibly knowing about the adultery that happened in the “Tour de Nesle affair” and was imprisoned as a result, but eventually her name was cleared.

Blanche of Burgundy (1322)

Sister of Joan II of Burgundy, she was the daughter ofÂ Otto IV, Count of Burgundy. She married the future Charles IV, and was yet another accused of adultery in the “Tour de Nesle affair.” She was imprisoned until her death. Yet another for whomÂ I can’t find an even vaguely-contemporary image of the real deal – again, maybe because of potential hoor-dom.

She was played byÂ Anne Malraux inÂ Les Rois mauditsÂ (2005), but I can’t find any images.

Joan of Burgundy akaÂ Joan the Lame (1328-49)

Daughter ofÂ Robert II, Duke of Burgundy, she married Philip IV; she had some kind of limp, hence the nickname. She served as regent while her husband fought on campaign, and was a scholar.

She was played by Claude Gensac inÂ Gaston PhÃ©bus, le Lion des PyrÃ©nÃ©esÂ (1978), but I can’t find any pics.

Tune in next week for the second half of my French queens run-down!
